title: Tiocem
text:
TioCem is a specialized <a href="cement">cement</a> with <a href="Photocatalysis">photocatalytic</a> features, used on the surface of buildings to reduce air pollution caused by exposure of the cement to <a href="ultraviolet">ultraviolet</a> light (UV).
Technology.
Photocatalysis is initiated by <a href="titanium%20dioxide">titanium dioxide</a> (TiO2), which is added during the cement's production. Typical properties (i.e. strength) of cement applications (such as concrete) will be added to clean the air around the photocatalytic surface. <a href="Nitrogen%20dioxide">Nitrogen dioxide</a> (NO2) will be particularly abated when daylight activates the photocatalytic surfaces.
The chemical process may be summarized as follows:
TiO2 + hν -> TiO2 + h+ + e-
H2O + h+ -> H+ + OH-
Using materials like TioCem, the abatement of NO2 could be measured by a test method using the Italian standard UNI 11247, which is being discussed as the basis of a European standard. This method involves test apparatus in which a mixture of air and pollutant flows in a chamber over a test object; the pollutant burden is measured with (and without) exposure to light. A defined level of NO2 abatement is guaranteed by the label “TX Active” (plus an initial) and replication of the test results.
Proof of the effective reduction of oxide-of-nitrogen exposure has been furnished under close-to-practical conditions by the PICADA (Photocatalytic Innovative Coverings Applications for Depollution Assessment) Project (supported by the <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a> and other studies.
Applications.
Since the photocatalytic effect is needed only on the surface of a building which is exposed to UV, Tiocem is used primarily in the top layer of a two-layer surface.

The abatement of NO2 varies with changing climatic conditions. Field tests were carried out with pavements in <a href="Bergamo">Bergamo</a>, <a href="Italy">Italy</a>, on the inside walls of a tunnel in <a href="Rome">Rome</a> and <a href="stucco">stucco</a> in <a href="Stockholm">Stockholm</a>. In all cases, the requirements of TX Active for NO2 abatement were met.
